name: Hong Kong
intro_vibe: Where East meets West in a vertical city of neon, dim sum, and skyscrapers.

general_info.description: Hong Kong is a Special Administrative Region of China and one of the world's most densely populated cities. A former British colony, it blends Chinese and Western influences into a unique culture. Known for its dramatic skyline, world-class cuisine, efficient public transit, and vibrant street life, Hong Kong operates as a global financial hub while maintaining deep cultural traditions.

etiquette_tips: Octopus Card is Life: This rechargeable smart card works on all public transit (MTR, buses, ferries, trams) plus 7-Eleven, Starbucks, and vending machines. Buy one immediately at any MTR station.
Queue Culture: Hong Kong takes queueing seriously. Form orderly lines for everything—MTR, escalators, restaurants, taxis. Cutting in line is social suicide.
Escalator Rules: Stand on the right, walk on the left. MTR escalators move fast and locals don't tolerate blockers. This rule is strictly enforced.
No Tipping: Service charge is included in restaurant bills (10%). Additional tipping is not expected or necessary. Rounding up taxi fare is polite but optional.
Name Cards Matter: In business settings, receive name cards with both hands and study them briefly before putting away. It's a sign of respect.
Shoes Off: Some traditional restaurants and all homes require shoe removal. Look for slippers by the entrance as a signal.
Chopstick Etiquette: Never stick chopsticks upright in rice (funeral symbolism). Don't point them at people. Place them on the rest, not the bowl.
Dim Sum Protocol: Share everything. Pour tea for others before yourself. Tap two fingers on table to thank someone for pouring your tea. Servers tally dishes at end.
Public Behavior: Keep voices down on MTR and in restaurants. Loud phone conversations are frowned upon. Public drunkenness is rare and embarrassing.
Respect for Elders: Give up MTR seats for elderly, pregnant women, and anyone with a baby. It's not optional—locals will judge you.

neighborhoods.name: Central
neighborhoods.description: The beating heart of Hong Kong's business district. Glass skyscrapers, luxury malls, and the famous Mid-Levels Escalator. Expensive restaurants and rooftop bars dominate.

neighborhoods.name: Tsim Sha Tsui
neighborhoods.description: Kowloon's main tourist hub on the harbor. Museums, luxury hotels, tailors, and the iconic Avenue of Stars. Best views of Hong Kong Island skyline.

neighborhoods.name: Mong Kok
neighborhoods.description: The densest neighborhood on Earth. Neon signs, street markets, electronics shops, and constant energy. Ladies Market and sneaker street are here.

neighborhoods.name: Sheung Wan
neighborhoods.description: Traditional Chinese medicine shops next to hipster cafes. Dried seafood wholesalers beside art galleries. The gentrifying edge of old Hong Kong.

neighborhoods.name: Causeway Bay
neighborhoods.description: Hong Kong's retail epicenter. Massive malls, department stores, and street-level shops. Locals come here to shop, eat, and hang out.

neighborhoods.name: Sham Shui Po
neighborhoods.description: The most authentic Hong Kong neighborhood. Electronics markets, fabric wholesalers, and cheap street food. Minimal English, maximum character.

logistics.title: Getting Around
logistics.summary: Hong Kong has one of the world's best public transit systems. Fast, clean, and intuitive.
details: MTR (Metro): The backbone. Covers all major areas, runs 6am-1am, air-conditioned, signs in English. Get an Octopus Card (HK$50 deposit + starting balance).
Trams: The iconic double-decker street trams run along Hong Kong Island's north shore. Dirt cheap (HK$3), slow, charming. Board at back, exit at front, pay when leaving.
Buses: Extensive but confusing for tourists. Double-decker buses go everywhere. Use Citymapper app for routes. Pay exact change or Octopus Card.
Star Ferry: The legendary harbor crossing between Kowloon and Hong Kong Island. HK$3-4, runs since 1888. Take it at sunset for magic.
Taxis: Plentiful and cheap. Red (urban), green (New Territories), blue (Lantau). Drivers rarely speak English—have address in Chinese. Octopus accepted.
Walking: Central/Admiralty/Sheung Wan are walkable. Use the extensive system of covered walkways and escalators connecting buildings.
Minibuses: Green (fixed routes) or red (flexible routes). For advanced users only—drivers speak no English and routes are mysterious.

logistics.title: Airport to City
logistics.summary: Hong Kong Airport (HKIA) is on Lantau Island, connected to the city by fast rail and bus.
details: Airport Express Train: Fastest option (24 mins to Central). HK$115 one-way. Runs 5:50am-12:48am. Buy Octopus at airport or use credit card at gates. Free shuttle buses from stations to hotels.
Airport Bus: Cheaper (HK$40-50) but slower (45-60 mins). Routes go to every district. A21 goes to Tsim Sha Tsui, A11 to Causeway Bay. Comfortable and air-conditioned.
Taxi: HK$250-350 to Hong Kong Island, HK$200-250 to Kowloon. Follow queue signs—don't accept street offers. Red taxis only (urban). 30-50 min depending on traffic.
Hotel Shuttle: Many hotels offer private transfers. Expensive (HK$500+) but convenient with luggage.
Pro Tip: If arriving late (after midnight), taxi is your only option. Airport Express stops at 12:48am.

logistics.title: Safety & Scams
logistics.summary: Hong Kong is one of the world's safest cities. Violent crime is rare, but tourist scams exist.
details: Overall Safety: You can walk anywhere at any time. Violent crime against tourists is virtually nonexistent. Women traveling alone feel safe.
Common Scams: Fake monks asking for donations (ignore them). 'Massage' card girls in Tsim Sha Tsui (legitimate spas don't street promote). Overpriced tailors targeting tourists.
Taxi Scams: Rare. Meters are used and honest. If driver refuses meter, exit immediately. Make sure they turn on meter at start.
Restaurant Scams: Some seafood restaurants in tourist areas inflate prices or add hidden charges. Check prices before ordering. Avoid places with aggressive touts outside.
Pickpockets: Minimal but watch belongings on crowded MTR during rush hour. Keep valuables in front pockets.
Protests: Political demonstrations happen occasionally. Avoid them entirely—police response can be intense. Check news before travel.
Lost Property: Report to police. There's a good chance you'll get it back—Hong Kongers are honest and the city has extensive CCTV.

logistics.title: Money & Payments
logistics.summary: Hong Kong Dollar (HKD) is the currency. Cards widely accepted but cash still king in local places.
details: Currency: HK$1 ≈ $0.13 USD. Coins: $0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 5, 10. Notes: $10, 20, 50, 100, 500, 1000. Three different banks print notes—all legal tender.
ATMs: Everywhere. 7-Eleven has ATMs. Withdraw from HSBC or Bank of China for best rates. Most accept international cards (Visa, Mastercard, UnionPay).
Credit Cards: Visa and Mastercard accepted at restaurants, malls, and hotels. Many small shops and dai pai dongs are cash only.
Octopus Card: The secret weapon. Rechargeable smart card works on all transit, 7-Eleven, McDonald's, Starbucks, vending machines. HK$50 deposit + initial value. Top up at MTR stations or 7-Eleven.
Exchange: Avoid airport (terrible rates). Use city money changers in Central or Tsim Sha Tsui (Chungking Mansions has good rates but chaotic). Banks also exchange.
Tipping: Not expected. 10% service charge automatically added to restaurant bills. No tips for taxis, MTR, or casual dining. High-end restaurants may expect small extra tip.
Bargaining: Expected at street markets (Ladies Market, Temple Street). Start at 50-60% of asking price. Not acceptable in malls or regular stores.

logistics.title: When to Visit
logistics.summary: October-December is peak season. Summer is hot and humid. Avoid Chinese New Year if you hate crowds.
details: Best Time: October-December. Dry, sunny, comfortable temperatures (18-25°C). Perfect for hiking and outdoor activities. Highest prices.
Good Time: January-March. Cool and dry. Chinese New Year (late Jan/early Feb) is festive but crowded and expensive. Book 3+ months ahead.
Avoid: June-September. Typhoon season, extreme heat (32°C+), oppressive humidity (80-90%). Daily rain showers. Everything is air-conditioned to arctic levels.
Budget Travel: April-May or September. Shoulder season with lower prices but increasing humidity and rain. Still good for city exploration.
Festivals: Chinese New Year (biggest), Dragon Boat Festival (June), Mid-Autumn Festival (September), Christmas lights (December).
Typhoons: Tropical cyclones hit June-October. Typhoon signal system: T1 (be aware), T3 (stay indoors), T8+ (everything shuts down). Hotels stay open. Can be exciting.
Pro Tip: November has clear skies, low humidity, perfect temperatures, and lower prices than October. The secret best month.

logistics.title: Language & Communication
logistics.summary: Cantonese is the main language. English signage is everywhere but spoken English varies.
details: Official Languages: Cantonese (90%), English (official but limited proficiency), Mandarin (increasing).
English: All MTR signs, street signs, and tourist areas have English. Government and business use English. But many locals speak limited English, especially elderly.
Cantonese Basics: Learn 'M̀h'gōi' (thank you) and 'Nei hou' (hello). Even basic attempts are appreciated. Pronunciation is tonal—don't worry about getting it perfect.
Written Chinese: Traditional characters (not simplified like Mainland China). Even if you read Mandarin Chinese, some characters differ.
Restaurant Strategy: Many local restaurants have English menus or picture menus. Point at what others are eating if you can't read the menu. Google Translate camera feature helps.
Apps: Download Google Translate offline Cantonese. Pleco dictionary app. WhatsApp is the main messaging app in Hong Kong.
Getting Help: Young people and service industry workers speak better English. Hotel staff and tourist information centers are fluent.

logistics.title: Health & Medical
logistics.summary: Excellent healthcare system. Tap water is safe. Pharmacies everywhere.
details: Healthcare: World-class. Public hospitals are cheap but crowded. Private clinics and hospitals are expensive but fast. Get travel insurance.
Tap Water: Safe to drink. Hong Kong has high water quality standards. Hotels and restaurants serve it freely.
Pharmacies: Watsons and Mannings are everywhere. Open late. Most medications available without prescription (antibiotics, etc). Pharmacists speak some English.
Emergency: Dial 999 for ambulance/police/fire. English operators available. Queen Mary Hospital and Prince of Wales Hospital are major public hospitals.
Pollution: Air quality can be poor (especially summer). Check AQI levels if you have respiratory issues. Wear a mask if needed—it's culturally normal.
Heat & Humidity: Summer humidity causes heat exhaustion. Drink water constantly. Seek air-conditioned spaces. Locals use parasols for sun protection.
Mosquitoes: Dengue exists but rare. Use repellent if hiking or in parks. Urban areas have minimal mosquitoes.
Clinics: Central Health Medical Practice, OT&P Healthcare. Expect HK$500-1000 for consultation.

logistics.title: Essential Apps
logistics.summary: These apps will make navigating Hong Kong infinitely easier.
details: Citymapper: THE transit app for Hong Kong. Real-time MTR, bus, ferry, and walking directions. Better than Google Maps for public transit.
MTR Mobile: Official app with route planning and service updates. Shows which exit to use at stations.
OpenRice: Hong Kong's Yelp for restaurants. Reviews in English and Chinese. Essential for finding good local spots.
WhatsApp: Everyone uses it. Free calls and messages. Download before arrival.
WeChat: Needed for some Chinese businesses and Mainland friends. Not as essential as in Mainland China.
Google Maps: Works perfectly in Hong Kong (unlike Mainland China). Offline maps recommended.
Deliveroo / Foodpanda: Food delivery. Massive selection. English interface. Late-night lifesaver.

description.short: The quintessential Hong Kong culinary experience, featuring bite-sized portions of steamed, fried, and baked delicacies served in bamboo baskets.
description.history: Originally a snack for travelers on the Silk Road, it evolved in Hong Kong into the 'Yum Cha' tradition, where families gather for morning tea and conversation.
description.insider_tip: If a server pours your tea, tap two fingers on the table to say 'thank you' without interrupting the conversation. Order 'Har Gow' (shrimp dumplings) to test a chef's skill.

description.short: Succulent goose roasted to perfection with mahogany-crisp skin and tender, flavorful meat, often served over rice with a tangy plum sauce.
description.history: A labor-intensive specialty of Cantonese cuisine, traditional Hong Kong roast goose is often prepared in charcoal-fired ovens for a distinct smoky depth.
description.insider_tip: Visit the legendary Yat Lok in Central or Kam's in Wan Chai, but arrive 15 minutes before they open to secure a seat without a 2-hour wait.

description.short: Al dente egg noodles served in a clear, dried-flounder broth with plump shrimp wontons hidden beneath the noodles.
description.history: A working-class staple that rose to fame in the 1940s. The 'Hong Kong style' is defined by the noodles' distinct snap and the broth's umami depth.
description.insider_tip: Real wonton noodles are served in a small bowl with the spoon at the bottom to prevent the noodles from getting soggy in the broth.

description.short: A silky, bright yellow egg custard nestled in either a crumbly shortcrust or a multi-layered flaky pastry shell.
description.history: A hybrid creation born from British custard tarts and Portuguese pasteis de nata, adapted by Hong Kong's 'Cha Chaan Tengs' (tea cafes) in the 1940s.
description.insider_tip: Flaky crust (sau pei) is more traditional for afternoon tea, while shortcrust (tai pei) is often found in local bakeries. Tai Cheong Bakery is the most famous spot.

description.short: A soft, sweet bun topped with a crackly, sugary crust, served warm with a thick slab of cold, salty butter inside.
description.history: Contains no actual pineapple; its name comes from the checkered, golden-brown crust that resembles the fruit's skin.
description.insider_tip: The 'Pineapple Oil' (Bo Lo Yau) version is the pro choice—the contrast between the hot bun and the melting cold butter is essential.

must_eat.name_local: 絲襪奶茶 (Si Mat Naai Cha)

description.short: A potent blend of several types of black tea mixed with evaporated milk, known for its creamy texture and high caffeine kick.
description.history: Also known as 'Pantyhose Milk Tea' because the tea is traditionally strained through a fine sack that resembles a silk stocking.
description.insider_tip: Order it 'Yuenyeung' to get a local favorite mix of 3 parts coffee and 7 parts milk tea for an even bigger energy boost.

description.short: Strips of boneless pork marinated in a sweet honey and five-spice mixture, then roasted until caramelized and tender.
description.history: The word 'Char Siu' literally means 'fork roasted,' referring to the traditional method of skewering the meat on long forks over a fire.
description.insider_tip: Ask for 'Bun Fei Sau' (half fat, half lean) to get the perfect balance of melt-in-your-mouth fat and savory meat.

description.short: Silky, translucent rice noodle sheets rolled around fillings like shrimp or beef, drizzled with seasoned sweet soy sauce.
description.history: A dim sum staple that originated as a street snack. The best versions are made by hand-steaming rice batter on a cloth.
description.insider_tip: Street-style Cheung Fun is often served plain in a roll with sesame seeds, hoisin sauce, and peanut sauce—very different from the dim sum version.

description.short: Rice cooked in a clay pot over an open flame with toppings like preserved sausage, chicken, or beef, resulting in a crispy, charred bottom layer.
description.history: A seasonal winter favorite in Hong Kong, traditionally cooked over charcoal to give the rice a distinct smoky aroma.
description.insider_tip: Don't scrape the bottom immediately; let the pot sit for a few minutes with the lid on to ensure the rice 'crust' becomes perfectly crispy.

description.short: A highly customizable bowl of noodle soup where diners choose their noodle type, broth, and a variety of toppings like pig blood curd or daikon.
description.history: Born in the 1950s when street vendors sold noodles from wooden carts to refugees. It remains the ultimate 'choose-your-own-adventure' budget meal.
description.insider_tip: Don't be afraid of the 'weird' toppings; braised chicken wings and honey-glazed pig skin are local favorites that add great texture.

description.short: Thick slices of white bread with a peanut butter filling, egg-washed and deep-fried, then topped with golden syrup and a pat of butter.
description.history: A decadent example of 'Canto-Western' fusion cuisine that emerged in local tea cafes to satisfy a Western-influenced sweet tooth.
description.insider_tip: Pour the syrup generously. It is a calorie bomb meant to be shared as a snack, not eaten as a healthy breakfast.

must_eat.name_local: 咖喱魚蛋 (Ga Lei Yu Dan)

description.short: Spongy, bouncy balls made of fish paste, simmered in a rich, mildly spicy yellow curry sauce and served on a skewer.
description.history: The undisputed king of Hong Kong street food. It is estimated that Hong Kongers consume millions of these daily.
description.insider_tip: Look for vendors in Mong Kok or Sham Shui Po where the curry sauce is bubbling and thick; if the sauce looks like water, move on.

must_eat.name_local: 皮蛋瘦肉粥 (Pei Dan Sau Yuk Juk)

description.short: A thick, silky rice porridge flavored with bits of preserved 'century egg' and tender strips of lean pork.
description.history: Regarded as the ultimate healing food in Chinese culture, congee is easy on the stomach and often eaten for breakfast or late-night supper.
description.insider_tip: Order a 'Yau Zaa Gwai' (fried dough stick) on the side to dip into the congee for a satisfying crunch.

description.short: A honeycomb-shaped waffle with bubble-like pieces that are crispy on the outside and soft and cakey on the inside.
description.history: Legend says it was invented by a grocer who used broken eggs to make a batter so they wouldn't go to waste. Now a global street food icon.
description.insider_tip: Eat them plain first to appreciate the malted egg flavor before trying trendy versions with chocolate or matcha.

description.short: A communal dining experience where fresh raw ingredients are cooked in a pot of simmering broth in the center of the table.
description.history: In Hong Kong, hot pot is a year-round social event, though it is most popular during the brief, chilly winter months.
description.insider_tip: Create your own dipping sauce at the condiment bar—garlic, scallions, soy sauce, and a little chili oil is the standard local base.

description.short: The highest point on Hong Kong Island, providing the world-famous view of the skyscraper skyline and Victoria Harbour.
description.history: During the colonial era, the Peak was an exclusive residential area for Europeans; the Peak Tram was built in 1888 to facilitate their commute.
description.insider_tip: Skip the long Peak Tram queue by taking the #15 bus from Central Ferry Pier; it's cheaper and offers stunning winding-road views.
description.best_time: Sunset (watch the city lights flicker on)

description.short: A legendary green-and-white ferry service that has been shuttling passengers across Victoria Harbour for over 130 years.
description.history: National Geographic rated this as one of the '50 places of a lifetime.' It remains one of the world's most affordable and scenic public transits.
description.insider_tip: Sit on the upper deck for better views, or the lower deck to hear the water slap against the hull and smell the sea air.

description.short: A synchronized laser and light show involving over 40 skyscrapers on both sides of Victoria Harbour.
description.history: Launched in 2004, it is recognized by Guinness World Records as the world's largest permanent light and sound show.
description.insider_tip: The best viewing spot is the Tsim Sha Tsui waterfront near the Clock Tower; download the show's app to listen to the synchronized music.

description.short: A massive 34-meter high bronze statue of Buddha sitting serenely atop a mountain on Lantau Island.
description.history: Completed in 1993, the statue faces North toward Mainland China, symbolizing the stability of the region and the prosperity of the people.
description.insider_tip: Take the Ngong Ping 360 cable car (Crystal Cabin) to get there—the glass floor offers a thrilling view of the forest below.

description.short: A lively nocturnal bazaar in Kowloon filled with street food, trinkets, fortune tellers, and opera singers.
description.history: Often used as a backdrop for triad films, it is the last place in Hong Kong where you can truly feel the grit and energy of old Kowloon.
description.insider_tip: Walk to the end near the temple to find the fortune tellers—some even have trained birds that 'pick' your fortune card.

description.short: A kilometer-long stretch of street stalls in Mong Kok selling everything from clothing and bags to quirky souvenirs.
description.history: Established in the 1970s, it earned its name for the sheer volume of low-priced women’s clothing and accessories once sold here.
description.insider_tip: Bargaining is mandatory; start at 50% of the asking price and be prepared to walk away to get the best deal.

description.short: A creative landmark housed in a revitalized historic building, now filled with local designer boutiques and art galleries.
description.history: Formerly the Police Married Quarters, the site was saved from demolition and transformed into a hub for Hong Kong's creative industry.
description.insider_tip: Check the central courtyard schedule—there are often high-end night markets or international art installations occurring on weekends.

description.short: A stunning, incense-filled temple dedicated to the gods of Literature (Man) and War (Mo).
description.history: Built in 1847, it is one of the oldest and most important temples in the city, once serving as a court for resolving community disputes.
description.insider_tip: Look up to see the giant spiral incense coils; they can burn for weeks and fill the temple with a thick, mystical haze.

description.short: A sprawling Taoist temple complex famous for 'Kau Cim'—a form of fortune telling using bamboo sticks.
description.history: Dedicated to a legendary monk who achieved immortality, it is the most popular temple for locals seeking medical advice or career fortunes.
description.insider_tip: Even if you don't speak Cantonese, you can pay a small fee to have your bamboo stick's number interpreted by an English-speaking fortune teller in the adjacent arcade.

description.short: A traditional Tanka fishing community famous for its stilt houses built over the tidal flats of Lantau Island.
description.history: Known as the 'Venice of the Orient,' it offers a glimpse into Hong Kong's past as a series of humble fishing outposts.
description.insider_tip: Take a 20-minute boat ride for HK$20 to see the stilt houses from the water and try to spot the rare pink dolphins in the bay.

description.short: A stunning ridge-line hike that offers panoramic views of Hong Kong Island’s coastline and the South China Sea.
description.history: Voted by Time Magazine as the best urban hike in Asia, it connects Wan Chai to the surfer village of Big Wave Bay.
description.insider_tip: The trail ends at Big Wave Bay beach; bring your swimwear and have a celebratory beer and pizza at the local beach shacks.

description.short: A coastal district known as the 'Back Garden of Hong Kong,' famous for its pristine beaches, volcanic rock formations, and seafood.
description.history: Once a quiet fishing port, it is now the gateway to the UNESCO Global Geopark and the city's premier weekend escape.
description.insider_tip: Take a 'sampan' (small boat) from the pier to Sharp Island for some of the city's best snorkeling and clear water.

description.short: The world's longest covered outdoor escalator system, spanning 800 meters and climbing over 135 meters in elevation.
description.history: Built in 1993 to provide a better commute for residents of the Mid-Levels, it unintentionally became a major tourist attraction and nightlife hub.
description.insider_tip: The escalator moves downhill in the morning (6-10 AM) and uphill from 10 AM to midnight; plan your walk accordingly.

description.short: One of the world's highest bars, located on the 118th floor of the ICC tower in West Kowloon.
description.history: Designed by Masamichi Katayama, the bar's futuristic 'honeycomb' interior matches the dizzying heights of the Ritz-Carlton hotel.
description.insider_tip: Check the weather before going; if it's a foggy day, you will be sitting in a cloud with zero visibility.

itinerary.title: Dim Sum at Tim Ho Wan
itinerary.description: Start with Michelin-starred dim sum. Order BBQ pork buns, har gow, siu mai, and turnip cake.

itinerary.title: Central & Mid-Levels Escalator
itinerary.description: Explore Central's skyscrapers, ride the world's longest escalator, visit Man Mo Temple.

itinerary.title: Roast Goose Lunch
itinerary.description: Michelin-starred roasted meat at Yat Lok or Kam's. Half goose over rice for HK$100.

itinerary.title: Victoria Peak
itinerary.description: Take bus 15 to skip tram queue. Panoramic views of skyline, harbor, and mountains.

itinerary.title: Star Ferry Sunset
itinerary.description: Take the legendary harbor crossing at golden hour. HK$4 for one of the world's great journeys.

itinerary.title: Symphony of Lights & Night Market
itinerary.description: Watch the 8pm light show, then explore Temple Street Night Market for chaos and curry fish balls.

affiliate_products.name: Octopus Card Holder
affiliate_products.reason: You'll tap it 20+ times daily on MTR, buses, and convenience stores.

affiliate_products.name: Portable Phone Charger
affiliate_products.reason: Constant use of maps and camera drains batteries fast.

affiliate_products.name: Compact Umbrella
affiliate_products.reason: Sudden downpours common. Typhoons June-September. Locals carry year-round.

affiliate_products.name: Cooling Towel
affiliate_products.reason: Summer humidity (32°C + 80%) is oppressive. Instant relief when wet.
